sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Southern Way. Southern Colonies and the Growth of Slavery (1660-1700). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Thomas, age 14, son of a small tobacco farmer in Virginia, 1690.

sections.section: Chapter 1: Life on a Small Farm
sections.narration: My name is Thomas, and I am fourteen years old. My family owns a small tobacco farm in Virginia. We're not wealthy planters with hundreds of acres—we have just fifty acres and grow enough tobacco to make a modest living. Unlike the huge plantations, we don't own enslaved workers.
visuals: Chapter title: Life on a Small Farm
sections.key_takeaway: My name is Thomas, and I am fourteen years old.

sections.narration: Our neighbor, Mr. Randolph, is a wealthy planter. He owns a plantation with two hundred acres and twenty enslaved workers. I've seen them working in his fields from dawn to dusk, supervised by an overseer with a whip.
visuals: Chapter title: The Growth of Slavery

sections.narration: The Southern colonies are different from each other. Virginia and Maryland grow tobacco. South Carolina grows rice in coastal swamps where the work is brutal and deadly. The rice fields must be flooded and drained, and workers labor in water up to their knees, plagued by mosquitoes and disease.
sections.key_takeaway: The Southern colonies are different from each other.

sections.narration: I've been thinking a lot about what Father said. How did we get here? How did English colonists who came seeking freedom create a system that denies freedom to others? Father explained that it started gradually.
sections.key_takeaway: I've been thinking a lot about what Father said.

sections.narration: Last week, three enslaved people escaped from Randolph's plantation. They disappeared into the forest, heading north. Randolph hired slave catchers with dogs to track them. Two were caught and whipped publicly as a warning.
sections.key_takeaway: Last week, three enslaved people escaped from Randolph's plantation.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored The Southern Way through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Plantation, Cash Crop, Slavery, Middle Passage.
